awd_titl_txt: Conference: Recent advances in the mechanistic understanding of avian responses to environmental challenges
awd_abstract_narration:
This conference award supports participants in a symposium and associated poster session on understanding avian responses to environmental challenges, at the annual meeting of the Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB) in January 2024. Birds inhabit some of the most variable and extreme environments on the planet, and recent advances in the lab and field have led to discoveries about the mechanisms that enable birds to overcome physiological challenges of all kinds, including extreme long-distance flight, heat and cold, osmotic challenges, low oxygen, and immune challenges. The symposium will advance the collective understanding of the physiological strategies that birds use to survive in challenging environments, and to promote discussion among the participants in an attempt to establish new and strengthen existing connections, find common themes, and discuss future directions in the field. By bringing together physiologists with disparate expertise from various career stages and backgrounds, including undergraduate and graduate students in the poster session, common themes will be identified and new approaches that promote future innovation and collaborations will be discussed. Participants will prepare a synthetic, forward-looking paper to be published in the SICB journal, Integrative and Comparative Biology. The individual symposium presentations will also be published and disseminated in the same journal issue.

Birds are among the most widely distributed endotherms on the planet, living in many types of inhospitable environments. In the face of environmental challenges, the basic principles that allow for survival can be similar among species, even in response to very different challenges. However, the underlying mechanisms, suite of physiological responses, and selection on those traits differ significantly, and their influence and impact from an ecological or evolutionary perspective can vary as well. It is the goal of the supported symposium to highlight physiological mechanisms underlying avian responses to environmental challenges and to facilitate the synthesis of new discoveries with established findings in order to provide an informed understanding of the current state of the art in the field, to highlight new tools, and to identify future research opportunities and collaborations. Furthermore, one of the many enduring impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic is that early-career researchers have not had as many opportunities to network, develop professional relationships, or present their research in a way that maximizes exposure to the research community. Therefore, the symposium specifically highlights the excellent research being conducted by early-career scientists, with an emphasis on promoting women in science. The symposium also includes a number of more senior avian researchers to develop and broaden mentoring networks among the speakers. In addition, the participation of five or more undergraduate and graduate students in a complementary poster session will provide current students the opportunity to build important professional relationships.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funds generously provided by NSF-IOS helped sponsor the full-day symposium “Recent Advances in the mechanistic understanding of Avian responses to Environmental challenges” at the annual Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology meeting held in Seattle from January 2-7 2024. We had an extremely successful symposium hosting 10 speakers (listed below) representing career stages from postdoctoral fellows to Full professors.  We also hosted complementary speaker and poster sessions providing opportunities for 7 more graduate students and others to share and discuss their work with the symposium participants. Many of the speakers also had graduate students attending that participated in the discussions and social activities that added to the success of the symposium.  We hosted a social and networking event on the first night of the conference, which built camaraderie amongst the participants that led to numerous shared meals and socials throughout the week. Feedback received from participants indicated that this social event was especially appreciated by early-career individuals that had not previously attended many (or any) meetings in the past, due to COVID limitations, and that this opportunity was the highlight of their meeting! This was especially rewarding for us as organizers because we know from our own experiences that connections of this kind can inspire future collaborations and be hugely influential on career trajectories.

Proceedings of this symposium were published in Integrative and Comparative Biology (see references) and attendance at the talks was very high, filling the provided room to capacity for all the talks.  All papers from this symposium were published in the december issue of Integrative and Comparative Biology (V64 I6)



Symposium Speakers:

  1. Alexander Gerson, Associate professor, UMass Amherst, 

Symposium Introduction.

  1. Maria Stager, Assistant Professor, UMass Amherst

The genetic architecture underlying avian flexibility in a complex physiological trait

  1. Cory Elowe, Postdoc, UMass Amherst

The influence of calcium regulation on migratory and thermoregulatory phenotypes of songbirds

  1. Catherine Ivy, Postdoc, Univ. Western Ontario

Maintaining oxygen uptake and movement to the flight muscle during migratory flight in songbirds

  1. Jessie Williamson, Postdoc, Cornell University

Extreme elevational migration spurs cryptic speciation in giant hummingbirds

  1. Phred Benham, Postdoc, UC Berkeley

Integrative approaches to studying intraspecific physiological adaptation to environmental change

  1. Wendy Hood, Professor, Auburn University

Bioenergetic adaptations to migration in White-crowned Sparrows

  1. Leo Fusani, Professor, Konrad Lorenz Institute of Ethology

Physiological adaptations for migration influence how birds respond to environmental changes

  1. Jenny Uehling, PhD Candidate, Cornell University

Experimental glucocorticoid elevation alters activity and dietary choices in a wild songbird

  1. Jamie Cornelius, Assistant Professor, Oregon State University

Beyond thermogenesis: seasonal variation in response to reduced food in captive crossbills

 

Complementary sessions:

i) Emma Rhodes, PhD Candidate, Auburn University

Mitochondrial capacity in two Mimidae species: a migratory and non-migratory comparison

ii) Davide Dominoni, Lecturer in Urban Ecology, University of Glasgow

Chronobiology of urban life: New insights from parallel recording of activity and body temperature.

iii) Kevin Young, PhD Candidate, Western University

Do n-3 Polyunsaturated fatty acids reduce energy costs in Western Sandpipers?

iv) Juan Zuluaga, PhD Candidate, University of North Carolina, Wilmington

Thermography and behaviorial analysis reveal novel mechanisms of seasonal acclimatization

v) Elizabeth Rogers, PhD Candidate, University of Massachusetts, Amherst

Using ∆17O to estimate metabolic and exogenous body water inputs in captive house sparrows

vi) Atalanta Ritter, PhD Candidate, Indiana University, Bloomington

Heat and Repeat: Do wild birds habituate to consecutive thermal challenges?

vii) Audrey Su, Undergraduate, Cornell University

Effects of cold and experimentally elevated glucocorticoids on incubation behavior in Tree Swallows
